ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I really appreciated learning from people in a variety of fields. Professor Schmidt-Camacho and Professor Pitti also had fantastic comments about everyone's work. It was very helpful to learn from how they facilitated the course.

This working group introduced me to graduate-level collaborative research skills. I learned how to provide constructive feedback to my peers. I strengthened my abilities at primary source analysis and close-readings of seminal theory. Through everyone's shared writings, I learned about the richness and diversity of the field of Latinx Studies. From history, to cultural studies, to urban studies, to history of medicine, I was exposed to many modes of thinking and writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely - this course was a great way to workshop my own work in a supportive environment and I gained a lot of valuable feedback. I also really appreciated how everyone in the class learned from each other.

Yes, this course helped be have an inspiring and enjoyable first semester of grad school. The feeling of community and family established through this group was sentient, and it made class exciting and personally meaningful. As a class that will help you work on your writing, receive knowledgable feedback, and be exposed to fresh new scholarship from peers, this course was invaluable.
